talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr Truss

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: The Inter-Governmental Agreement (IGA) specifically commits the parties to the following reforms:
to cap extractive use of water from all surface and groundwater systems that are over-allocated or approaching full allocation;
removal of impediments to the effective operation of trading markets in, and the integrated management of, both surface and ground water systems;
controls on land clearing which prohibit clearing where it leads to unacceptable land and water degradation.

Through bilateral agreements the States and the two mainland Territories have committed to: policy and institutional reforms in regards to water property rights; appropriate pricing of water; introducing regulatory reforms for water and land use to motivate best practice in land and water resource management; establishing regional bodies to develop integrated and strategic natural resource management (NRM) plans; and a national standards and targets framework and monitoring and evaluation strategy.

These agreements also secure national commitments through complementary processes such as the Council of Australian Governments (COAG) 1994 water reform agenda, the national vegetation framework and the Murray-Darling Basin strategies.

Regional bodies are established by the States and Territories, in most cases under legislation, and are therefore operating under arrangements defined by these jurisdictions. The Australian Government is working with State and Territory Governments and regional bodies to ensure best practice governance arrangements for regional bodies.
A copy of the Review of the NAP Governance and Control Framework dated March 2004 has been provided to the honourable member and is available from the Table Office.
The IGA outlines the outcomes that the Australian Government is seeking to achieve including:
capping extractive use of water from all surface and groundwater systems that are over-allocated or approaching full allocation;
removal of impediments to the effective operation of trading markets in surface and groundwater systems;
controls on land clearing which would lead to unacceptable land or water degradation;
development of national criteria that will be the basis for accreditation of integrated regional NRM plans;
establishment of community-based regional bodies to develop the regional NRM plans;
development of regional NRM plans that improve salinity and water quality.
The Bilateral Agreements reinforce the IGA and the COAG 1994 water reform commitments.
Negotiations to commit the States and Territories to these and other related outcomes delayed the conclusion of the NAP bilateral agreements.

The policy reforms in the IGA and bilateral agreements reinforce the COAG 1994 water reform commitments. They also include additional regional arrangements (such as establishing regional bodies and undertaking integrated regional planning process) and vegetation reforms. Developing and implementing the NRM plans will contribute to delivering the commitments and national policy reforms agreed to by COAG.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: Grants were paid to Australian Business Limited and the Australian Industry Group under the Austrade administered Export Market Development Grants (EMDG) scheme in 2003-04 and 2004-05. Details of these grants are as follows:

The purpose of EMDG grants is to assist small and medium sized Australian businesses to enter export markets and become sustainable exporters by reimbursing up to 50 per cent of eligible export promotion expenses they incur above $15,000. The maximum grant is $150,000 and a maximum number of seven grants is payable to an individual recipient. Eligible export promotion expenses include marketing visits, overseas representation and marketing consultants, participation in trade fairs, communications, free samples, promotional literature and advertising, and visits to Australia by overseas buyers. Eligibility for an EMDG grant is determined in accordance with specific eligibility criteria as set out in the Export Market Development Grants Act 1997.

The scheme makes a provision for peak industry associations to seek âspecial approval statusâ to enable them to apply for a grant. Under this provision, eligible business associations can apply for a grant as an Austrade âApproved Bodyâ.

To qualify for âApproved Bodyâ status, an association must be the âpeakâ industry body for the industry it represents and must be undertaking generic export promotion on behalf of its members. To be a âpeakâ industry association, an applicant must be able to demonstrate that it ârepresents the majority of businesses engaged in that total Australian industryâ. Austrade determines if a body meets these requirements in accordance with a Ministerial Determination.

* Section 94 of the Australian Trade Commission Act 1985 authorises Austrade to provide only certain limited details of grant recipients (name, address, industry, grant amount) to third parties. Therefore, the exact date of payment of EMDG grants cannot be provided.

item.para: CASAâs strategic direction is underpinned by high-level goals, which in order to be achieved, must be supported by a range of safety related actions. Within this context, CASA has determined that where appropriate, greater emphasis will be placed on using data analysis in the decision making and planning process within CASA.
One of CASAâs objectives is to identify and address the most significant safety related trends and risk factors in the system of civil aviation safety in Australia.

As outlined in CASAâs 2005-2006 to 2007-2008 Corporate Plan, a series of initiatives have been developed to enhance CASAâs safety research and analysis capability. These initiatives include: resources reporting directly to the Chief Operating Officer; development of research and analysis strategies to support standards development; the development of cooperative research and analysis programs within CASA and with regulatory authorities, aviation organisations, universities/colleges and manufacturers; and conveying results of safety research and analysis to stakeholders.

In the past year, CASA has initiated a number of data analysis projects aimed at improving aviation safety. Of particular importance was an extensive analysis of fatal accidents in the general aviation sector. This project was undertaken within CASA and did not involve the use of any external consultants.

As the program is being embedded in CASAâs decision making processes, it is difficult to provide detailed costings. Eligible clients may also choose to purchase a hearing device with additional features (referred to as a âtop-upâ device). Choosing a âtop-upâ device requires the client to contribute to the additional cost associated with the device.

These arrangements provide clients with access to a wide range of hearing devices, while protecting those least able to purchase devices by providing them with access to a series of devices that are available at no cost to the client.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Ageing, in writing, on 9 August 2005:

quote.para: Why is the Continence Aids Assistance Scheme terminated for people when they turn 65, regardless of the severity of their medical condition.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: The Australian Government provides support for people with incontinence through a range of national services. Specifically, continence advice, information and support is provided through the National Continence Management Strategy and National Continence Helpline on 1800 330 066 (free call). In addition, some financial assistance for products to help eligible people with permanent incontinence is provided through the Continence Aids Assistance Scheme (CAAS) and the Stoma Appliance Scheme.

The CAAS was set up by the previous Government as an employment-related scheme in which assistance was provided to people in the 16-64 years age group. The Scheme was designed to help people with incontinence remain in the workforce by assisting with the financial barrier continence management can cause to participation in education and employment. The CAAS was intended to complement State and Territory Schemes and was never intended to cover the full cost of continence aids.

The CAAS continues to provide some limited assistance to people over the age of 65 years, though only where applicants are involved in paid work of at least eight hours per week and where their income and asset levels are such that they are eligible for an income support benefit.

The Australian Government provides assistance to States and Territories through the Commonwealth State/Territory Disability Agreement to provide aids and equipment for people with disabilities. The State and Territory Governments administer a range of schemes, set their own eligibility criteria and determine the range of aids supplied. The CAAS was intended to complement these State and Territory schemes. It was not intended to replace existing schemes of assistance. Most States and Territories fund schemes that provide continence aids for people with disabilities, except Western Australia.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, in writing, on 9 August 2005:

item.para: Is the Minister aware that pensioner couples in receipt of Utilities Allowance receive the same amount of Allowance as pensioner singles.

Can the Minister confirm the basis for differential payments between pensioner couples and singles that have shown single people need a higher level of income to maintain a standard of living similar to that of couples.

Which studies has the department relied on to establish the current position and, in respect of each study, (a) what year was it completed, (c) who was its author, and (d) which areas in Australia or which overseas countries were the focus of the study.
Will the Minister commission a taskforce to investigate the current real average living costs of pensioners; if not why not.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: Yes.

The social security system recognises that single pensioners need more income to have a similar standard of living to, and run a household like, couples. Couples gain economies and advantages from living together. Single people cannot usually share costs, such as electricity, telephone, heating and house maintenance.

The differential rate of pension paid to members of a couple and single pensioners was introduced in 1963. No single study can be considered as specifically determining the relativities. The relativities of pension payment rates have been subject to extensive consideration, in the context of formal reviews of aspects of the social security system, ongoing analysis within the Department of Family and Community Services and its predecessors and debate within the academic and wider community.

As data on the real average living costs of households, including pensioners is available from the regular Household Expenditure Survey undertaken by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, there is no need for a taskforce to be established for this purpose.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, in writing, on 10 August 2005:

item.para: Does he support the introduction of comparative assessments of:

item.label: (a)
item.para: teacher performance; and

item.label: (b)
item.para: school performance within and between Australian education systems; if not, why not.
In the reporting of comparative assessments can he say how allowance will be made for:

item.label: (a)
item.para: differences in the educationally-relevant background characteristics of students; and

item.label: (b)
item.para: gains in studentsâ educational attainments arising from their participation in private tutoring programs outside of school.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr Nelson

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: The Australian Government has endorsed the MCEETYA National Framework for Professional Standards for Teaching, to help identify the key elements (knowledge, understanding, skills and values) of effective teaching. The Framework acknowledges that the nature and content of professional teaching standards developed at the local level will vary according to their purpose and context. Professional teaching standards therefore provide a possible mechanism for assessing teacher performance. The profession, through the National Institute of Quality Teaching and School Leadership, has commenced the development of advanced standards to identify highly accomplished teachers and school leaders.

The Government strongly supports performance-based pay for teachers. Salary advancement for Australian teachers is currently almost exclusively based on an incremental scale, reflecting longevity of service and experience rather than qualifications or teaching performance. The Australian Technical Colleges, funded by the Australian Government, which will be senior secondary schools which provide students with trade training, will provide their teachers with access to performance pay and will offer them the option of an Australian Workplace Agreement. The broader implementation of performance pay however would be a matter for the education authorities that run schools and employ teachers.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The Australian Government is committed to ensuring parents receive more meaningful information about school performance in order to assist them in making decisions about their childâs schooling.

In order to assist parents, the Australian Government is making State and Territory funding conditional on a range of measures being implemented. A key requirement is that, from 2006, State, Territory and non-government education authorities will have to ensure that each school makes available to parents information about the performance of the school. This information will encompass key student outcomes including the percentage of students achieving literacy and numeracy national benchmarks, professional engagement including teacher qualifications and teacher attendance, and information about parent, student and teacher satisfaction. Schools may publish other material about the school as they see fit.

quote.para: All Education Ministers have agreed that the publication of league tables is not supported (MCEETYA resolution, May 2005).

item.label: (a)
item.para: The National Goals for Schooling in the 21st Century, endorsed by all education Ministers in 1999, provide that âSchooling should be socially just, so that: studentsâ outcomes from schooling should be free of negative forms of discrimination based on sex, language, culture and ethnicity, religion or disability; and of differences arising from studentsâ socio-economic background or geographic locationâ. They also state that âthe learning outcomes of educationally disadvantaged students [should] improve and, over time, match those of other studentsâ.

When they endorsed the National Goals for Schooling, Ministers directed that work commence on the development of national performance measures in key areas of schooling, including literacy, numeracy, science, ICT and civics. Recognising that the capacity to obtain a national picture of the educational progress of students is affected by the variety of definitions of student groups used by different States and Territories, school systems and schools, Ministers also directed that common national definitions of student background characteristics be developed and put in place across Australia.

The development of both national performance measures and definitions has been the job of MCEETYA taskforces of State and federal officials, most recently the Performance Measurement and Reporting Taskforce.

Since 1999, reporting in the Annual National Report on Schooling in Australia (the ANR) on student achievement in each State and Territory against national literacy and numeracy benchmarks has gradually expanded to cover Years 3, 5 and 7, disaggregated by sex and for Indigenous students and students of language background other than English. In 2003, reporting by student geolocation (metropolitan, provincial, remote and very remote) was introduced.

The national definitions and data collection mechanisms needed for reporting in the ANR according to studentsâ socio-economic background are being implemented as from 2005, with full reporting expected from 2006.

The Schools Assistance Regulations build on the MCEETYA definitions by requiring that the performance measures to be included in the ANR each year will include information disaggregated according to the student characteristics noted above, using the definitions approved by MCEETYA. The Regulations also require that this information will be reported not only for literacy and numeracy, but also for the national sample surveys in science, ICT and civics which will occur over the 2005-08 quadrennium.

The provision of school performance information (see 1b above) will require schools to give a description of the value they add to studentsâ learning. Typical of this kind of analysis is the reference to relevant background characteristics of students that schools may wish to include.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The Australian Government acknowledges the differing backgrounds and experiences of students, but nevertheless is committed to the expectation that all schools can and should deliver high standards of achievement for their students. The key imperative driving this commitment is a desire to see all children, regardless of their background, experiences and opportunities, including access to private tutoring, achieve minimum standards in literacy and numeracy to enable their successful participation in schooling, further study, training and work.

In relation to the impact of private tuition on studentsâ achievement, a review of the Aboriginal Tutorial Assistance Scheme (as part of a review of the Indigenous Education Direct Assistance Programme) found that individual tuition can make a difference to performance where the needs of the student are clearly matched with the expertise of the tutor. (The Scheme provides funding for extra tuition for Indigenous students who are assessed by their relevant educational institution as needing some tuition over and above that which is normally provided by the institution.)

The Australian Government is funding a pilot Tutorial Voucher Initiative. This in an innovative and practical measure designed to be additional to any other assistance children may receive during school hours. The pilot was developed to enable access to valuable one-to-one tuition delivered outside school hours.

An independent evaluation is running concurrently with the pilot Tutorial Voucher Initiative. It is investigating the impact of the pilot on student reading development, and the effectiveness of the pilot as a means of assisting children who did not meet the Year 3 national reading benchmark in 2003. The evaluation will provide valuable information for the development of future programmes in literacy. The Department expects to receive a final report early in 2006 after the pilot ends.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Vocational and Technical Education, in writing, on 10 August 2005:

Will the development of a replacement training package take account of new water management strategies and practices?

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
talker.role: Minister for Vocational and Technical Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister
talker.name: Mr Hardgrave

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The scoping (first) phase of the review of the National Water Industry Training Package (NWP01) was undertaken in 2003 and the final report from this phase was noted by the National Training Quality Council in December 2003. Work has already been undertaken in re-validating the 2003 Phase 1 scoping report and a Steering Committee has been formed to guide Phase 2. The initial scoping phase of the review was undertaken by the National Training Advisory Ltd (the Local Government ITAB). Since this time, new industry advisory arrangements have been put in place for the new national training system, and the newly established Government Skills Australia ISC has taken up the project, which is seen as a high priority.

The current version of the National Water Industry Training Package was endorsed by the National Training Quality Council on 21 September 2001. State Training Authorities are responsible for implementation of Training Packages once they have been endorsed.

The current National Water Industry Training Package was recommended for review by September 2004. This is a recommendation, not a requirement, and the current package remains in implementation until the review is complete.

Phase I of the review of the National Water Industry Training Package was completed in December 2003. The development phase of the review has now commenced, with the appointment of a Steering Committee, comprising representatives from a broad range of national and State-based industry organisations and training providers. As part of the review process, comprehensive consultation will be undertaken with relevant industry stakeholders, including the water industry in all States and Territories, training providers, key government agencies, employer and employee associations, and the community.
Government Skills Australia is the Industry Skills Council responsible for the National Water Training Package.
During the consultation process, the review of the National Water Industry Training Package will consider any new water management strategies and practices.

The reviewed National Water Industry Training Package will be submitted for endorsement to the National Quality Council after the completion of the review process, in September 2006. Following National Quality Council endorsement, the Training Package will be ready for implementation by all States and Territories.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 17 August 2005:

item.para: Can he explain the Governmentâs policy in relation to the receipt and use of counter-terrorism related information from foreign governments that the Australian Government knows or reasonably suspects was obtained from persons by means of torture or other inhumane means.

On how many occasions since September 2001 has the Government made representations to any foreign government concerning the suspected torture of persons when the alleged torture has been associated with obtaining intelligence or security information subsequently provided to Australia by that foreign government.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The Governmentâs policy is that it does not support the receipt or use of information obtained as a result of torture or other inhumane means. The Government does not condone the use of torture in any circumstances. The Government supports international action against torture and deplores such behaviour wherever and whenever it can. Australia has ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which proscribes torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Australia has also ratified the United Nations Convention against Torture and other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment.
The Australian Government does not comment on intelligence matters.

and (2) The Government was informed on 17 April 2002 that Mr Habib was in US custody in Afghanistan. The Government is not aware how Mr Habib came to be in Afghanistan, nor is it aware of the date on which Mr Habib came into US custody.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: The Australian Government rejects and strongly condemns the use of torture in any circumstances. talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, in writing, on 18 August 2005:

talker.name: Mr Andrews

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: Yes - I was a guest speaker at the event.
Yes.

No funding was provided for the function. The event was aimed at showcasing the work undertaken by Hillsong Emerge in testing the success of Micro Enterprise Development (MED) in three regions of Australia, being Redfern and Mt Druitt in Sydney, the Many Rivers Region on the north of NSW and Cape York in far north Queensland. The Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation provides a continuing approval service for each particular wine product that is destined for export. The fee for continuing approval is $54.45 for packaged wine or $137.50 for bulk wine. Sensory evaluation by qualified wine inspectors employed by the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. The cost of this evaluation is included in the continuing approval fee; and

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, in writing, on 18 August 2005:

item.para: Austrade has completed its review of the EMDG scheme. It submitted its report on this review to the Minister for Trade on 30 June 2005, in accordance with the requirements of section 106A of the Export Market Development Grants Act 1997.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Representing the Special Minister of State, in writing, on 5 September 2005:

item.para: Has Woodhaven Investments been instructed by the Electoral Commissioner to submit an electoral return to disclose political donations it provided to Ms Lucille Bailie, a Liberal Party candidate in last yearâs ACT Legislative Assembly election.

What are the penalties for companies which fail to disclose political donations in accordance with the Electoral Act.
What penalties will be imposed on Woodhaven Investments and Nexus Pty Ltd if they have failed to disclose political donations in accordance with the Electoral Act.

talk.start.para: âThe Special Minister of State advises that the following answer has been provided to him by the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC):

item.para: and (2) No. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 (Electoral Act) requires disclosure of donations to candidates in federal elections only. It does not cover donations made to candidates in State or Territory elections.

However, where donations totalling $1500 or more are made in a financial year to a political party registered under the Electoral Act, the donor is required to lodge an annual financial disclosure return with the AEC. Donor annual financial disclosure returns for the 2004/05 financial year must be lodged with the AEC by 17Â NovemberÂ 2005 and become available for public inspection on 1 February 2006.
The maximum penalty applicable for failure to lodge a financial disclosure return is $5000 for a registered political party and $1000 for others.
Any such offences under the Electoral Act must be prosecuted through the courts and it is for the court to determine the level of penalty, if any, to be imposed.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 6 September 2005:

item.para: Has he seen reports that two journalists in Belarus, Andrei Obuzov and Pavel Morozov, are being prosecuted for âslandering the Presidentâ after posting a satirical cartoon on their website.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: Yes.

No specific protest has been made to the government of Belarus. The case relates to a student group called âthe Third Wayâ. The group operates a website that published animated cartoons satirising Belarusian politicians, including the President. The Minsk City Prosecutorâs Office has begun an investigation under Article 367 of the Criminal Code, which deals with instances of libel against the President and carries a maximum sentence of five years imprisonment. According to latest information, although three people are being investigated, none have yet been charged.

At the 61st session of the UN Commission on Human Rights, held in Geneva earlier this year, Australia co-sponsored a resolution on the human rights situation in Belarus. The resolution, which contained a reference expressing deep concern about restrictions placed on the media in Belarus, was adopted by a comfortable margin.
